Award.AwardTitle: Flourish: A Network for Pre-Tenure Social and Personality Psychologists of Color

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The fields of social and personality psychology succeed in part because of the diversity of their scientists. However, as scholars of color advance in the field they are less likely to find peers and mentors of color at their respective academic institutions. Reversing these trends is a top priority for personality and social psychological science. This project creates new and continuing opportunities for pre-tenure faculty of color to develop relationships with their peers and to connect with tenured faculty of color who serve as mentors. The activity – Flourish – is a year-round network for pre-tenure social and personality psychologists of color that includes an annual retreat and online workshops throughout the year. The retreat features participant- and mentor-led workshops on professional development, teaching strategies, and research productivity for scholars to strengthen their academic profiles and build a successful case for advancement. Year-round activities feature weekly collaborative writing spaces, meetings with peers and mentors, and tracking of professional achievements. Flourish provides a critical opportunity for retention within higher education, within the field of social/personality psychology, and expanding a pipeline of scholars who will serve as successful role models for future generations of faculty and scientists.

Faculty of color face unique challenges to advancement that hinder success at their respective institutions. These faculty members experience cultural, geographic, and professional forms of isolation especially when there are few faculty of color in their department or academic divisions. They can also be tasked with disproportionate amounts of service that disrupt teaching and research productivity, which are essential for career advancement. Strategic initiatives for diversifying science often focus on the recruitment stage but tend to neglect later stages of career development and advancement. Flourish offers resources for addressing challenges and mitigating negative consequences for tenure-track faculty of color by providing confidential spaces for sensitive discussions, expanding professional and social networks, affirming scholars’ positions, and promoting their work. Workshops dedicated to defining tenure/promotion guidelines, identifying institutional norms, and setting individualized goals provide a clear and precise support path designed to increase the likelihood of successful advancement. The ultimate goal of Flourish is to foster promotion, retention, and inclusion for faculty of color to diversify the field and research of social and personality psychology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary

 

Prior to NSF funding, Flourish began in 2020 as a retreat with 11 attendees following the annual meeting of the Society for Personality and Social Psychology (SPSP). With funding in 2022, the Flourish retreat had 37 attendees, in-person and online via Zoom. To celebrate Flourish’s growth and the accomplishments of Flourish members, the retreat featured a panel of three Flourish members who earned tenure since the 2020 retreat. This retreat also had a hybrid panel of three senior faculty, and a series of peer mentoring break-out sessions. After the retreat, there were year-round opportunities for people to engage and connect through weekly writing accountability sessions and the Flourish Slack channel. Additionally, Flourish hosted two three-hour, Caveday writing retreats in June and September of 2022, which were attended by 16 people. The 2022 cohort of retreat attendees completed three surveys about their experience with Flourish programming, their experience in SPSP, and their respective institutions. Over 90% of the participants were interested in attending Flourish again. The Flourish organizers used feedback from the surveys to prepare the next grant and support Flourish’s ongoing growth.


Intellectual Merit


The lack of racial diversity among faculty within social and personality psychology continues to be a significant challenge that impacts both the field’s scholarship and the ability to mentor the next generation of scholars. Faculty of color face unique challenges, including isolation, discrimination, and additional service work, making it harder to meet the research requirements for tenure. While college/university initiatives frequently focus on the hiring of diverse faculty, they often fall short in supporting faculty’s long-term success.


Flourish addressed these concerns by providing pre-tenure faculty of color with support and community. Our programming now supports a growing network of scholars. The program’s impact is evidenced by concrete outcomes, including successful tenure cases, new research collaborations, and an improved sense of belonging in the field. Indeed, survey data show that over 75% of participants from our 2022 retreat felt significantly or moderately more prepared to navigate the tenure track after attending the Flourish retreat, and nearly 70% reported increased feelings of inclusion within SPSP. By creating dedicated spaces for mentorship, professional development, and community building, Flourish is actively working to transform the field into one where pre-tenure faculty of color can not only survive but also thrive in their careers.


Co-organizers, Morgan Jerald and Angela Bell, have both presented in conference sessions about Flourish in 2023. In addition, the organizers published a paper in the journal Social and Personality Psychology Compass on the benefits reporting on the benefits of affinity group programs, like Flourish.


Broader Impacts


Flourish improves social conditions for social and personality faculty of color by providing an accessible and expanded professional network and increased social and emotional support opportunities. Through Flourish faculty of color are able to center, highlight, and address their unique experiences of being underrepresented in higher education. Moreover, such programming was designed to develop human resources by improving faculty’s teaching and research performance, skills, and attitudes that help improve promotion and retention as professors. For example, one retreat attendee transitioned to a new university and shared that encouragement during Flourish helped their performance on the job market and made them feel empowered in their position negotiations. Through this network, they found themselves at a new minority-serving institution that feels sustainable for their career. Further, two retreat attendees wrote a successful grant together and several others collaborated on a conference symposium. Flourish’s central aim of supporting a workforce of diverse faculty has several important downstream consequences for society. Participants who remain engaged in professional societies like Flourish will experience (1) teaching and research support that is better suited for their goals, (2) increase their collaborations that can bridge social and personality psychology disciplines, and (3) produce scholarship that can improve public knowledge through a more representative understanding of the human experience. This knowledge will also be disseminated to participants' students and mentees who contribute to public knowledge in their careers.
